title: How to peel sweet corn easily | How to remove corn kernels in 1 minute | Peeling Trick |Simple Trick

tasks.task: Take out corn kernels using a spoon
subtasks: Gather required tool (spoon)
Position corn ear for first row extraction
Mash and remove first row of kernels
Push remaining kernels out for easier extraction
Remove second row of kernels
Store extracted corn in freezer for up to 50 days
Serve corn raw or as sweet corn
Encourage viewers to try the method MAINTASK: Freeze corn kernels
Place extracted corn in freezer storage container
Label container with contents and date
Store container in freezer MAINTASK: Extract corn kernels
Position corn ear to access rows of kernels
Use spoon to remove kernels from each row
Continue until all rows are extracted
Peel garlic cloves
Chop garlic cloves finely with knife
Heat oil in pan
Add minced garlic and sauté until fragrant
Gather corn kernels, tomatoes, red onion, jalapeño, garlic, lime juice, salt, and cilantro
Combine corn, tomatoes, red onion, jalapeño in a bowl
Mix in minced garlic, lime juice, salt, and cilantro
Season to taste and serve alongside corn
Husk corn ears
Slice corn kernels off the cob
Store in airtight container MAINTASK: Husk corn ears
Grip corn ear by the base
Grasp the husk starting from the bottom
Tug upwards to tear off the husk
Remove any remaining silks or debris MAINTASK: Slice corn kernels off the cob
Hold corn ear at an angle on a cutting board
Use a sharp knife to cut kernels from the cob, moving towards the tip
Separate kernels into a collection bowl
Locate compost bin
Remove contents and discard non-compostable materials
Rinse bin with water or hose
Dry bin and store in designated area MAINTASK: Rinse a bride's table
Locate bride's table
Fill basin or bucket with water and mild detergent
Use sponge or cloth to wash table surfaces, working from the inside out
Rinse with clean water
Allow to air dry MAINTASK: Mow the lawn
Check lawn mower blade for dullness or debris
Start lawn mower and check for proper operation
Mow grass to recommended height, moving mower in a straight line or overlapping passes
